Claims Data API Websites

Note: This work is public and open-source, but some details about the process have been omitted for confidentiality.

The Product

The Centers for Medicaid and Medicare (CMS) maintain four FHIR APIs that allow providers, payers, and patients to securely access interoperable healthcare claims data: AB2D, BCDA, DPC, and Blue Button.

Goal

CMS wanted to identify barriers to adoption and increase the number of organizations using the APIs in production.

My Role

I led strategy for this effort and contributed to research, design, and front end development. I worked closely with a talented team of content strategists, product managers, and developers.

Highlights

  • 3 websites launched in 2025.
  • An average of 7,442 unique users visit the redesigned sites every week.
  • 33,647,348 beneficiaries served by these API websites (as of Nov. 2025).
  • AB2D experienced a 115% increase of average visitors per month after launch.
  • BCDA experienced a 68% increase of average visitors per month after launch.
  • Blue Button became one of the first government sites to leverage Astro for a fast, modern front-end framework (to our knowledge).
  • Published 8 revamped use cases and 1 major white paper based on realistic applications identified in user research.
  • CMS now emphasizes open-source, transparency, and developer UX across API documentation and resources.

Process

Phase 1: User Research

Methods

  • Exploratory user interviews
  • Journey mapping
  • Gap analysis

Findings

  • Pain points for developer users and non-technical users
  • Obstacles in the journey to production, including detailed feedback on the high technical barrier to entry
  • Gaps in API documentation
  • Updated value propositions informed by user experience
  • Use cases for each API, which were later used to publish case studies and white papers.

"It was just an email thread that went around that was like 'Is anybody interested in this? Does anyone have any utilization?' and that's how we got started."

â€” AB2D User

Phase 2: Standardization Strategy

I recommended that we apply research findings to improve the public website and documentation for AB2D, then extend this effort to other APIs. This strategy to standardize emphasized joint research efforts, a repeatable approach, and pre-built web templates that could be used across all four APIs.

Key Strategy Points

  • Leveraging USWDS
  • Content-first approach, with focus on developer experience (Dev-X)
  • The Diataxis framework
  • Rapid prototyping and usability testing
  • Universal information architecture and steps to onboard
  • Developing maintainable, reusable, user-validated web templates
  • Enabling all teammates to easily update the websites, even without front-end expertise

Phase 3: Design

Methods

  • Current-state analysis
  • Card sort
  • Competitive analysis
  • Usability testing
  • Web analytics

We spent several sprints mocking up and testing key user flows and improved documentation for a single API, AB2D. We could extend these learnings and to other APIs down the road to save time and to reinforce standardized practices.

Crucially, we kept in close contact with Product Managers and stakeholders from other APIs throughout prototyping. This ensured that designs were universalized for each API's unique features and user needs.

In testing, the majority of users sorted 34/36 task flows into the same category/page. This validated the robustness and accuracy of the new information architecture.

Phase 4: AB2D Implementation

Framework

  • Ruby + Jekyll + USWDS
  • Later, Blue Button became one of the first government websites to move to Astro

Approach

Designs were implemented in a staging environment on a page-by-page basis, allowing for simultaneous, agile development.

We used Markdown and TypeScript to create intuitive code components that extended USWDS within guardrails, allowing non-technical teammates to contribute to code.

After all pages had been implemented and user-tested, the full website was publicly launched at https://ab2d.cms.gov/.

Phase 5: Standardized Implementation

Since information architecture, layouts, and front-end templates were already built and validated by users, we were able to skip the design stage altogether and implement new content directly in staging.

We developed the following sites in weeks instead of months, then days instead of weeks.

  • 3 websites launched in 2025. Scroll back up to the highlights.
  • Other teams at CMS are using these open-source, standard templates to independently spin up similar websites.
  • Reduction in support requests from users following the release of improved sites and documentation.
  • Nava published a Case Study about this effort in the Annual Public Benfit Report.
  • Non-technical teammates have been able to successfully update and contribute to the API websites, proving maintainability. One content writer even made a blog.
